results.title: Judah Waten
results.creator_credit: Darrelyn Gunzburg, Elisabeth Knight and Film Australia
results.brief_description: In an interview conducted at his home in Victoria in December 1982, Judah Waten discusses his writing, his life, his Jewish background, political views and Russian, Yiddish and Australian influences on his writing, including the experiences of migrants. This is interspersed with brief remarks by a number of his friends, including Manning Clark, Justice Judith Cohen and Alan Marshall.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Darrelyn Gunzburg, Elisabeth Knight and Film Australia

results.title: Hard work and hope: Australia's Italians
results.creator_credit: Equality Press and Italian Historical Society
results.brief_description: Designed to enable Australian Studies students appreciate the role of migrant labour in Australia. Focuses on the theme of work as experienced by Italian immigrants both before and after World War II. Photographs, newsreel footage and moving footage from the Italian Historical Society documents the contribution of Australia’s Italians to the community through their work. Accompanied by a 19p. Teacher’s Guide.

results.title: No more secrets
results.brief_description: Explores the issues of Child Abuse and provides strategies for both children and adults to enable them to deal with “secrets” which children often feel obliged to keep to themselves.

results.title: No myth
results.creator_credit: Claire Jager and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: This video exposes the entrenched attitudes and myths surrounding Australia’s most hidden crime: domestic violence. “No Myth” was produced to explain why secrecy, shame and misplaced guilt accompanies domestic violence, and why women who experience it are frequently too scared, ashamed and isolated to confide in anyone.
results.description: This video exposes the entrenched attitudes and myths surrounding Australia’s most hidden crime: domestic violence. “No Myth” was produced to explain why secrecy, shame and misplaced guilt accompanies domestic violence, and why women who experience it are frequently too scared, ashamed and isolated to confide in anyone.

results.title: Superheroes
results.brief_description:
This performance art film features blue screen technology and the director/actor starring as every character in a parody of classic Hollywood superhero films.
Graduate work from RMIT media arts (BA Arts)
